citeinfo.origin: Dan Dauer, Kenneth Carpenter, Harold Marshall, Old Dominion University.
citeinfo.title: Chesapeake Bay Monitoring Program: Lower Chesapeake Bay Microzooplankton Study (January 1993 through December 1999)

pubinfo.publish: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Chesapeake Bay Program administered by Virginia Department of Environmental Quality

descript.abstract: This data set describes the seasonal composition and abundance of the microzooplankton in the lower Chesapeake Bay and 4 major tributaries. This category includes zooplankters less than 200 microns in size. Emphasis is on the temporal and spatial distribution and composition patterns of the major microzooplankton categories, and their relationships to water quality variables and other plankton components. These microzooplankton include copepod nauplii, barnacle nauplii, rotifers, loricated and non-loricated ciliates, polychaete larvae, cladocerans, sarcodinids, and others.
descript.purpose: The initial objective of this study is to determine the seasonal composition and abundance of the microzooplankton in the lower Chesapeake Bay and 4 major tributaries.
descript.supplinf: Information for this metadata was adapted from the Environmental Protection Agency Chesapeake Bay Program data page web site - www.chesapeakebay.net/data/index.htm. If above web sites change go to http://www.chesapeakebay.net.

attracc.attraccr: Taxon identifications, raw data sheets and other stages of the collection and analysis procedures are routinely checked by the principal investigator and laboratory chief for quality assurance.

dataqual.complete: The first year of the research represented a preliminary study limited to 10 stations (Park and Marshall, 1994). After the first year, the program was expanded to sample 14 stations.

method.methdesc: The first year of the research represented a preliminary study limited to 10 stations (Park and Marshall, 1994). After the first year, the program was expanded to sample 14 stations. Emphasis is on the temporal and spatial distribution and composition patterns of the major microzooplankton categories, and their relationships to water quality variables and other plankton components.

Chesapeake Bay Program Laboratory Method Code MI102. Each 1 l sample was allowed to settle for 72 hours and carefully siphoned to a 300 ml concentrated sample which were then combined. A two step settling and siphoning steps followed to produce first a 250 ml concentrate, which was next concentrated to 100 ml. This concentrate was sieved through 73 micron mesh net to trap microzooplankton >73 microns which were washed into a beaker, then placed into a settling chamber #1 for examination and counts. The filtrate was mixed and 3 5ml aliquots are removed and placed in settling chamber #2, with a buffered formalin solution (20%) added to bring the total volume to 25 ml. After 5 minutes of settling, 15 ml of the upper concentrate is removed and placed in settling chamber #3. The settling chambers were allowed to settle for 24 hours, then counts were made. The entire bottom surface of the settling chambers were scanned at 100x for chamber #1 and at 200x for chamber #2 and #3 using an inverted plankton microscope. Chamber #1 provides counts for the larger microzooplankters (>73 microns), Chamber #2 for groups generally between 40 and 73 microns, and Chamber #3 for small ciliates, etc., which separates the very small species from sediment etc. Counts were made as number of organisms per liter. Additional Preservative: Buffered Formalin.

procstep.procdesc: The following equation was used to convert raw counts to density (#/L) for each taxon identified: GROUP 2 OR THREE ARE MULTIPLIED BY 10 IN MAINSTEM AND 20 IN TRIBS SUM OF GROUP 1+(2* MULTIPLIER)+(3* MULTIPLIER) DEN_L = DENSITY PER VOLUME ((RAWCOUNT/MILLILITERS OF SAMPLE)*CONCENTRATION) /TOTAL VOLUME OF COMPOSITE SAMPLE WHERE RAW COUNT= NUMBER OF ORGANISMS COUNTED IN A CHAMBER CONCENTRATION=CONCENTRATION FACTOR {283.286}

overview.eaover: Microzooplankton (Entity); Attributes species composition and abundance.
